reviewText:
What you should know first:This is a visual novel with several endings. There is quite heavy subject matter, if you prefer to avoid that, this VN may not be for you. I've divided this review into two parts - gameplay and story/emotional impact of the game.

Thoughts, game-wise:I feel the execution of this game was done quite well. I've tried 3 or 4 different routes so far (there seem to be more to discover) and the way new content is presented as you make different choices flows quite smoothly, in contrast to some games where extra/different routes may seem a bit clunky. I really enjoyed the writing, clearly a lot of knowledge and research went into this, and it's nice to see an 18th, 19th century British literature influenced writing style. That said, it may be a bit stuffy to read at first and the characters seem very pompous, but that is due to the influences and style the game has. The art is quite gorgeous, and while eerie I think it is perfect for this VN. I felt that my choices do matter, and in trying to please everyone, ended up turning everyone away (one or more of the routes).

Thoughts, story-wise:You will be put into the head of someone who is depressed, quite literally. You'll follow her thoughts and inner dialogue. For me, I got irritated, but then reconciled in cycles, even if I knew that these thoughts cannot be controlled by the mind you are in. The dialogue hit me hard, because a lot of it was the eerily similar with conversations I would have with a friend, who would in real life, explain her mind like how Samantha does. The dynamics are captured very well, and hit me in a very personal, emotional spot. I've had ups and downs with said person, and the dialogue for both the good parts and bad parts are relatable and it hurt.

Conclusion:This game is amazing, to me. It made me feel emotions like The Cat Lady has been able to produce in me. It hits home and I relate to it from past experiences. I would try to find all the endings right this instance, if I didn't have exams. And I will - this game, after reading only a couple endings, has constantly been on my mind. [Edit: shortly before exams I found all the endings...] I know this game is not for everyone - if you don't like VNs, if you don't like depression and other heavy themes, please stay away. Subjectively, I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Let’s get one thing 100% cleared out of the way:

As the title may suggest, this is a pretty grim game.

Despite the fairly colourful visuals, there are some pretty heavy themes (one of which may or may not be clinical depression) going on, not to mention everyone seems pretty short with each other and prone to casually bringing up suicide and death.

That established, let’s look at this:

This game has a very interesting art style; like a water colour painting with some Lolita influences. Characters are sufficiently expressive, and there are some really beautiful shots and backgrounds to be seen. I don’t think this is going to be everyone’s cup of tea, but I can’t think of many other titles that had as distinctive art work.

The game also has quite a unique writing style, though not without faults. Clearly based on the writing that came out of the Romantic Era (or there about), the very formal and ‘proper’ pool of words used is entreatingly varied and vivid. It’s refreshing to read, and has some very effective descriptions. The game sometimes has an issue on delivering exposition, and can sometimes come on a little strong when hammering in a point, but overall, I would rate the writing fairly well.

As for the characters, there’s also some interesting things going on, but there are weaknesses. I thought the fact that every character was named after and KIND OF loosely based on old writers and poets was a nice touch, and fit the style of writing. There is certainly a varied cast, each carrying their own themes and touches, with a solid four romantic interests.* However, there’s a weird issue going on: everyone’s kind of short with each other. This makes sense for a lot of the pairings (Roberta and Georgina, for example, who are polar opposites), however everyone feels pretty quick to say aloud the faults they find in the others. Even when it’s meant in good grace and good fun, this comes up oddly often, and makes one or two characters straddle the line to being unlikeable (even if only unlikable for a single scene). Not sure if that’s got something to do with the writing style or anything, but it’s hardly a deal breaker, just an odd quirk.

Overall, I’d say the game was perfectly fine. It has its faults to be sure, and it was never going to be everyone’s kind of thing, but there’s a lot to like in there.

*Edit: I've been told it may not be straight up romance in all of the routes, or that it might be heavy subtext" etc. Be warned."

reviewText:
Both Asphyxia and its predecessor, Dejection: An Ode[vndb.org], are about gender-swapped versions of Romantic poets, and inspired by their real relationships with each other. I absolutely love visual novels with references to classic literature, and while reading Dejection, I was impressed with the writer's ability to imitate the style of that period without making it too dense for modern readers. I felt very empathetic towards both Samantha and Lillian, its only two characters, especially during one well-placed run-on sentence about Samantha's feelings. I couldn't wait to read more, and the next game managed to somehow exceed my already-high expectations.

Asphyxia makes the heroines of Dejection teenagers and sends them on a school trip in a semi-modern setting – there's modern technology, but still a very old-fashioned feel to everything – with several of their colleagues. This expansion of the world of the story doesn't seem to stretch the creator too thinly at all, however, as it is still beautifully written. And while the art in Dejection is very cute, the art in Asphyxia is downright gorgeous. It really fits the setting well, as does the lovely music.

Perhaps most importantly, Asphyxia really made me develop strong feelings for the characters – even more so than I had expected. I loved Samantha, and wished that I could help her overcome her problems, despite the fact that their similarities to my own would probably make that impossible. (mild spoilers:)I couldn't help but love and empathize with Lillian as well, because of how much I related to Samantha, whose feelings for Lillian are so real and believable. And while some of the other characters seemed irritating at first, they all grew on me as more dimensions of their personalities became evident. There were things I liked about them all, and the only thing I didn't like about their story was that it eventually had to end.

I recommend that anyone who's at all remotely interested download and read Dejection, which is both free and quite short, and then buy Asphyxia if they like it. Also, definitely read the notes in the “extras” section once you've played it. Even if you're an English major like me, there are bound to be some interesting details you didn't know that were referenced in the game! It's really a very well-researched project on top of its other great qualities. It's definitely on my list of favourite visual novels I've ever read.

reviewText: Asphyxia is a difficult visual short story. It's odd to hear games of this genre described as difficult
date: since they're barely games at all, but Asphyxia packs an awful lot of terribly trying reading into so small a package. The story is driven almost entirely by its cast, and if the author weren't so adept at creating excellent, if not particularly likable characters, the whole effort would have fallen flat on its face. And that's really the trouble with Asphyxia: You don't like the characters, but that's what makes them good characters. The protagonist is morose, obsessive, and horribly depressing, and the rest of the cast spends much of the story being cruel to one another. The whole thing would have ended up very Dickensian if not for all of the moments where the facades get dropped and it becomes evident that the characters are actually three-dimensional...Well, that and the lack of mutilations through horrible industrial accidents.\n\nI suppose I say all of that in order to say this: Asphyxia is worth your time, even though it's short, and even though it's utterly depressing. I was left with the impression that there was a ton of work packed into so short a story. Ebi-hime's knack for diction and characterization is difficult to come by in any medium, making it evident that they're a strong writer, if one that could benefit from an editor. I spotted quite a few grammatical errors in my playthroughs, and some of the petty squabbles between characters really just went on and on far longer than they needed to, belaboring the point that X and Y don't care for one another. Beautiful music and artwork contribute much to the story, making the characters and setting all the more engrossing. All things considered, Asphyxia isn't just worthwhile, it's really pretty good. It takes the reader through a wide range of emotions in a short period of time, leaving its audience exhausted and frustrated, but still wanting more.

reviewText:
I was drawn to this visual novel entirely by the art, music and concept. The artwork is very different to the more traditional anime style usually seen in visual novels, with a watercolour look and more classical character designs, all accentuated by the multiple pieces of music that accompany each section. It was however that setup which really caught my attention, as we have here interpretations of classical English poets reimagined as adorable students. Despite the change in age and gender, it’s fun to see traits from the real poets show through, my favourite example being the flirtatious and crafty Georgia Byron who certainly lives up to her namesake.

Honestly I could easily recommend purchasing Asphyxia purely on these aesthetic choices, but there is actually a story beneath them.  It’s extremely well-written, with some great character development and quite a few humorous moments. However… it’s a heavy story. Our main protagonist Samantha suffers some mental problems, contemplates suicide and spends a good portion of the story in a state of depression that, depending on your choice, can either get steadily worse or be overcome or even denied. I confess that I struggled to get through the story, not because it’s bad by any means, but because I personally couldn’t get into Samantha’s mind-set most of the time and found it difficult to go and make those darker choices to get the other endings, and some of those left an unpleasant feeling afterwards. But as I said do not take this to mean it’s bad, I commend the writers for tackling this topic with such maturity and it is written incredibly well, plus those darker moments make the happy and funny sections all the more rewarding and heart-warming.

Overall Asphyxia is a beautiful visual novel, with gorgeous artwork, lovely music and a charmingly unique setup, all wrapping a deeply emotional story. I highly recommend that you give it a try, but do be aware that it can get very heavy at times.

Let me just say that I haven't played many visual-novel style, indie-developed games. Life Is Strange is in my library, because who can resist time travel and the butterly effect colliding beautifully in a French-made game with beautiful indie music backing it? Yes, I compared it to Gone Home in my review, but that comes from its origins within the 3-D walking simulator type of game.


Basically, all you need to know is that Asphyxia is a game in which the major Romantic poets of the late 18th century are reimagined as cute schoolgirls. Does this work? I personally have to say that the author of the VN has certainly done his research, but also the characters are so beleiveable, so well-written, that there was hardly ever a moment where I thought, OK this is where they are making reference to something
hoursPlayed: what these middle-aged male authors said some 300 years ago
voteText:
because the characters are so beleivable, the source material has been worked in almost seamlessly. The VN's writer, Ebi-Hime, is definitely on my radar now.

A lot of the reviews are coming from the, completely optional, I might add, lesbian romance side of things, again drawing a comparison to Gone Home. There seem to be multiple endings, and while there are subtextual references to how Samantha feels around Lillian, there are certainly many endings where they do not end up as a couple. I appreciate that the relationship, while somewhat forced at times, can certainly not come to fruition in what is certainly meant to be a melancholie game. I would not have purchased this game in the first place, if it was yet another teen/LGBT drama that was forced out of contrivacy such as Gone Home, however the author gave it to his audience to make of it what they will.

Samantha Coleridge is certainly a protagonist you want to root for, while she drinks energy drinks and absinthe to the point of vomiting, and stands freezing in the Scottish countryside wondering just how to win her friendship (Optional/obvious lesbian relationship) back with Lillian, you will be a part of her thoughts, which is why this is a good novelization, and you will struggle with her. Of course I have a particular affinity for redheads, and suffice it to say that Samantha is cute, like the other characters in this game, I wasn't wholly on board with all the avenues that she takes, for instance, the cigarette smoking, Someone I wanted to like smoking cigarettes I could have done without, and I parsed through the text referencing it.

Pros:
A writer whose dedication to his/her craft shows throughout, with numerous references to Romantic poets.
Cute, redheaded protagonist, who doesn't fall victim to gender steryotypes.

Cons:
Everything just has to be LGBT for some reason. Don't get me wrong I work with gay people on a daily basis, but few people realize that less than 5% of people (at least here in the USA) so for such a small minority, they sure are outspoken. I'm not sure if this is the author's perspective, or if they are trying to appeal to a broader demographic, but it always illicits an eyeroll from me.

It's an indie game, so I can hardly count it against the game, but I wished there was a cast of voice actors/actresses.

Final Verdict:
7/10: Cute animated girls, with clever references and writing alluding to the major Romantic poets of the late 18th century. If not for the repetitive RPG-maker music and shoehorned and completely unneccessary lesbian/LGBT ties, it would have been best in its class.

reviewText:
At first, when I read the premise behind this game, I got genuinely angry.
I'm really sick of the Weeaboo obsession with school girls and anime art style. Like seriously.

And to besmirch the great Romantics by portraying them as bickering, simpering school gir--
Wait a minute....
The Romantics acted just like a bunch of adolescent school girls! In this instance, it works!

And does it ever! It is so gratiating, thought-provoking, and geeky to read this Romantic-themed visual novel that focuses on the troubled  Sam(antha) Taylor Coleridge's obsessive and dependent relationship with the conservative Wi(llian) Wordsworth.

I was also a bit respulsed to see a curator recommending this because of it exploring alternative sexualities. That isn't the point of the narrative. It isn't fan service. There is no Hentai. It is about the very real fascination and agrandizement that many of the Romantics had with William Wordsworth, and briefly mentions the rumours that Byron has bisexual relationships-- but not with any of the characters in the game.

So don't be fooled by the appearance of this game. It's not a perverted anime visual novel. It's a serious reflection on all of the major themes of Romanticism-- the innocence of childhood, the corruption of adulthood, and the nostalgia for the past. The game focues heavily on the issue of logic vs. feelings, the issues with excess, and takes place in an ideal and beautiful natural setting.

I recommend it for anyone struggiling with depression, too, as Samantha will be as mirror-like as still water in some ways.

reviewText:
Have you ever wondered what it would be like to be a depressed teenage girl based off of a British romantic poet? No? Well, you should.

Asphyxia is a grim game that wholly deserves the attention of all its readers. Don't be deceived by the cute art, the game focuses on the worrying condition of the protagonist and the troublesome life she follows. Any fan of literature will enjoy this game, as it feels like a classic novel. But, whether you know the poets or not, the game does a splendid job of getting you into the characters. If you do know the poets though, you'll find your nerdy poetry loving heart a little tickled as there are a number of things you'll just /get/. In the extras, there are biographies of the poets that you can read for more insight as well.

The writing is great and it captures the condition of Samantha perfectly. Samantha is a realistic character and if you read through it and find yourself unable to relate to all her plights, know that I have. This game had me leaning over to see if my secret stash of angsty poetry had been invaded.

I can say that I don't regret this at all, and I don't think many people will. It's a wonderful piece of writing and it sweeps you along into all the emotions involved. It's grim, emotional, depressing and a great experience.

Now...if only it was longer....

Asphyxia revolves around Samantha, a teenage girl suffering from severe depression. They are going on a school trip and she has to come to face some people she'd rather avoid. reviewText:
Simply Incredible...

(I'll try to make this spoiler free)

You will be enticed by the story in no time. Unlike anything I've read, truly a wonderful experience. It's another gem by Ebi-hime, however this is a very different VN. The characters are loosely based off of the romantic poets of the past like Samuel Coleridge and William Wordsworth, but with a modern twist. Their relationship in the game shadows their relationship as it was in real life all those years ago. It makes for a very unique and interesting story and I thought it was a nice touch; plus you learn a lot. The dialogue is all very well spoken, it feels like reading an old book, still very enjoyable. Each character has their own story that you want to know more about, and they all eventually grow on you.

It's a darker story dealing with depression, love, and loss. It has some cute moments, but a little gloomy. Ebi-hime's writing is incredibly emotional and touched my heart. There are many different endings. The art is breathtaking, reminiscent of watercolor paintings. It has beautiful music as well.

It is now one of my favorites and I found myself only playing for little bits at a time because I didn't want it to end... The story will stick with you even after you've played it. I am confident you will love it.

-
Thank you Ebi-hime for the smiles and tears. You are very talented so never stop writing.

reviewText:
Asphyxia is a short visual novel with a handful of choices. Each choice has dramatic impact on the outcome of events. My first play through was completed in 2½ hours including some time alt tabbed while I searched for other games done by Ebi-Hime. The art and soundtrack are beautiful and fitting for the atmosphere of the game.

Asphyxia, at first, comes off as grandiloquent, however, this unifies with the florid motif of the rest of the game into a harmonious and concerted aesthetic.

If you're still reading after that last sentence then you'll be just fine with the diologue in this game.

Perhaps because I've been struggling, and losing, with exactly the feelings we see Samantha trying to understand within herself, having tried desparatly to reconcile these feelings in exactly the same ways she did, and am ultimately considering the same solutions she has, I may be not be as objective in my review. However, as each person, no matter how hard they try to avoid it, carries the baggage of their lives with them and has their view of the world coloured by their own experiences, it is impossible to be absolutely objective; why not indulge in subjectivity instead!

I don't feel that the subject matter in this game is particularly grim, rather, it is an exploration of the human condition. It addresses the fears and insecurities one faces when building and nurturing real relationships. It is a love story but not a love story in the romantic sense; It is about the idea of love as a basic need and what value it holds to us at our core. It is about our need for acceptance and how this is handled. You will not find a heartwarming story about overcoming trials and becoming stronger person. You will not feel the warmth and tenderness of a blossoming romance. What you will feel is the helpssness, emptyness, and fragile life of somebody who constantly wears a smile to hide their desperate stuggle to find even the smallest reason to live.

Asphyxia will leave you with a heavy sense of dissatisfaction. It is not a comfortable story and it does not leave you with a sense that everything will be okay in the end.

That is precisely the reason I love it.

Asphyxia is not a game for everybody. In fact, I think it's not a game for most people. Asphyxia is a game for people who feel deeply and often; those of us who interpret and communicate with the world through our emotions rather than thought even though we know, intimately, that we will get hurt in the end.

I finished reading the whole thing a couple of hours ago. Granted it is rather short but the art style is ridiculously gorgeous and so full of detail + the writing is so good it just makes everything work. The story is rather depressing and really draws you into feeling what the main character (Samantha) feels. It lets you know how depression and anxiety work and how terrible they both can be when mixed together. I only got the first three Steam achievements and I am excited to get the rest. My favorite character has to be hands down Georgia Byron.

10/10 Better believe it. That's my score right there!

I know it is short but I don't mind short visual novels at all when the writing is that good and makes you feel a certain way that is too real and allows you to connect with the characters to the point where you attach yourself emotionally to them. Also the background music goes hand in hand with the visual novel's overall aesthetic. This is probably the more serious 'review' I've tried to take my time to write because I feel like Asphyxia deserves it.

Please give this Visual Novel by ebi-hime a chance. I'm sure you won't regret it unless it ends up being far too depressing for you. Also, the writing was trying to emulate the writing style of a certain era just so we're clear here and you understand that it's not being overly pretentious by doing this or anything. Ebi-Hime thought it would be a great idea to use real life poets as cute girls doing cute things in her own wonderful and emotionally driven visual novel.

If you go to the 'Extras' section you'll get interesting information on who each character is based on.
Sorry for the lengthy review! I am madly in love with this visual novel, as you can see.

I will confess that I bought Asphyxia because it was recommended for people who wished to have an experience with a homosexual romance. The appearance seemed genuine as well so I gave it a go.

I sadly can not recommend Asphyxia. Though the artwork is very stunning and has a lot of work going into it, that is about it. I'm quiet frankly sad to say I would rather have seen an artbook with these pictures than paid full fare for Asphyxia.

The gameplay is almost none existing. Now, I've played these interactive stories before and I've come across a lot of them where, while there are much text, there are also a lot of choices in between these texts, equally divided and that actually seems to impact your story greatly. Asphyxia throws waves upon waves of text at you and just a few meagre choices that are only affecting the ending you'll get. The text is trying very hard for a melodramatic tone but I found myself feeling like most of it was simple filler and I will confess that after my first play through I simply turned on the “skip text” option so that I could unlock all the endings.

There is not a bad idea in Asphyxia and once more the artwork is stunning but there is too much text and to little choices. If this game should fall into the interactive novel point there needed to be more concentration on the interactive spectrum of the genre.

reviewText:
Though it has its charming moments and is complemented by some often gorgeous watercolour-esque art I can't recommend Asphyxia to everyone. Some will like it and many might love it but many will be bored or frustrated by it . That said, this is the kind of story that I'm always happy to see more of in games, one with progressive themes that aspires to be something literary, even if it is ultimately bland and the the crudely obvious references to English Literature are grating. It contains the characters 'Alexandra Taylor Coleridge' and 'Lillian Wordsworth', which are much more than gentle nods.

The story is grounded in reality, telling a tale of teenage depression and angst, but its characters and their conversations are not (perhaps fitting the literature it is, by the author's admission, inspired by). The characters do not speak like real people. Most of the time they sound as if they have been plucked from an A Level essay. You get used to it, but it is often jarring and gets in the way of telling a convincing story about love and friendship. Conversations also tend to carry on far too long, with characters repeating themselves or stating quite plainly how they feel about their relationships.

Despite all this though, by the end of a playthrough I was not left feeling bitter towards the game as I was when I was halfway through. It has its humerous moments and at least some of the cast of at first immensely unlikable characters eventually endear themselves to you which I will assume, to be kind to the game, was the intent. This is a classic example of a game that teeters between a thumbs up and a thumbs down. I enjoyed it just enough to recommend it (and perhaps that's simply because I played it a day after visiting the Lake District myself) though I know many would regret their time with it. It is by no means a must play but I am glad that it exists.

A note on interactivity:
There are few points at which you can make choices to diverge the story and the protagonist is very much their own character, and quite a frustrating character at that. You have no real means of shaping who they are. This is very much a story about them, not you. If you want a visual novel that lets you adopt a role like that I would recommend something by the wonderful Hanako Games, like Magical Diary. In fact, the most important diverging point in Asphyxia, the one that pretty much defines how the story ends, doesn't even present itself as a decision of any significance.

reviewText: To put it simply, I found this visual novel uninteresting.  If the game wasn’t so short, I’m sure I would have quit early on.  As it is, I only tried it since it came with a bundle.  I get the impression that I’m supposed to feel for the main character, but I could not get invested in her or the other characters.  A big issue is that the tone of the game always felt off.  The visuals are beautiful, but the characters look like children when they are supposed to be high school seniors.  Even the teacher looks like a child.  The setting seems like it is taking place in old timey England, but then we see the characters have cell phones and explicitly state that this is the twenty-first century.  Much of the dialogue is rather verbose and repetitive, and there were large tangents that didn’t really contribute to the narrative.  It got to the point where I was not interested in seeing what happens and just wanted to get to end.  It doesn’t help that the game keeps referencing an incident from the past but doesn’t explain what it was except in one ending.  Even then, it doesn’t really explain why that incident causes the heroine’s life to fall apart.  Flashbacks would have helped in setting the tone and help garner sympathy for the heroine.  Overall, I came in expecting to be depressed but ended up being bored instead.
